message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Smoking and asbestos exposure both increase the risk for developing bronchogenic carcinoma, a type of lung cancer. Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are both types of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) that are also associated with smoking, but not specifically with asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer affecting plasma cells in the bone marrow and is not directly linked to smoking or asbestos exposure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Both asbestos exposure and smoking increase the risk of developing bronchogenic carcinoma, a type of lung cancer. Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are also associated with smoking, but not with asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is not related to either smoking or asbestos exposure.

We refer to medical literature regarding the effects of smoking and asbestos exposure. Both smoking and asbestos exposure are associated with an increased risk of developing bronchogenic carcinoma (lung cancer), but not specifically chronic bronchitis, emphysema, or multiple myeloma. Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are caused by smoking but are not specifically linked to asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that affects plasma cells and is not directly linked to either smoking or asbestos exposure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Both smoking and asbestos exposure significantly increase the risk of developing bronchogenic carcinoma (lung cancer). While chronic bronchitis and emphysema are also associated with smoking, they are not specifically linked to asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of the plasma cells and is not linked to asbestos exposure or smoking.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Smoking and asbestos exposure are both known risk factors for the development of bronchogenic carcinoma (lung cancer). Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are also associated with smoking, but not specifically with asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is associated with exposure to certain chemicals, but not with smoking and asbestos exposure.

We refer to reliable sources, such as the National Cancer Institute, for help. Smoking and asbestos exposure are both significant risk factors for developing lung cancer, specifically bronchogenic carcinoma. Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are both chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD) that are more strongly associated with smoking than asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that affects plasma cells and is not directly linked to either smoking or asbestos exposure.

Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are also associated with smoking but not asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is not associated with either smoking or asbestos exposure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Both smoking and asbestos exposure increase the risk of developing lung cancer, specifically bronchogenic carcinoma. Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are also associated with smoking, but not with asbestos exposure. Multiple myeloma is associated with exposure to ionizing radiation and certain chemicals, but not with smoking or asbestos exposure.

We refer to medical resources on the web for help. Both smoking and asbestos exposure increase the risk of developing bronchogenic carcinoma (also known as lung cancer). Chronic bronchitis and emphysema are types of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) that are mainly caused by smoking, while multiple myeloma is a type of cancer of the plasma cells that is not related to asbestos exposure or smoking.
